chapter.title: Offline Validation Tool
chapter.para: When you ingest data files for &PRODUCT;, the ingestion process includes validating your data files. To minimize the risk of handling validation errors during ingestion, your preparation steps should include validating your data files and correcting any invalid content. You can perform this validation using an open source Offline Validation Tool (OVT) provided as a free download from the &COMPANYABBR; Github repository (&GITHUBURL;).
This section covers how to install and use the OVT.

section.title: System Requirements
section.para: The OVT has the following system requirements:

listitem.para: 50 Mb available space for the tool
Extra space for validating the XML file: a minimum of double the file size of the XML file you are validating
Write permission to the home directory of the tool

section.title: Using the Tool
section.para: Use the following procedure to set up and run the OVT:

step.para: Click the following sequence to navigate and download the OVT:
Your web browser should begin downloading the file OfflineValidationTool.zip. If necessary, specify where you want to save the file on your local computer.
Unzip the file you downloaded (OfflineValidationTool.zip) into a folder on your computer, such as C:\OfflineValidationTool. This is the application directory for the tool.
The application directory includes the following:

listitem.para: The lib directory contains the dependent libraries.
The ingestion-validation-1.0-{version}-SNAPSHOT.jar file is the executable file for the tool.
The OfflineValidationTool.sh file is a script for running the tool on Unix and Linux platforms.
The OfflineValidationTool.bat file is a script for running the tool on a Windows platform.

step.para: Run the script appropriate for your local computer using the corresponding steps below.
Open the Run command dialog. This may be in your Start menu, or you may need to press the Windows key + R to open it.
As an alternative, you can also open the Windows command prompt application and enter the command from there.

Use the dialog browse and select OfflineValidationTool.bat from the application directory. Then, place your cursor in the text box and add the path to the zip file you want to validate (shown as "$ZipFilePath" here):
Click OK to run the command.

para.emphasis: On a Linux- or UNIX-based system, including a Mac:

step.para: Open a terminal application on the system; on a Mac, you can start Terminal.app under Applications/Utilities/.
Make the shell script file executable from the command line:
Run the shell script using the path to the zip file you want to validate as an argument to the command (shown as "$ZipFilePath" here):

section.title: View the Results
section.para: Output from the OVT consists of the following:

listitem.para: A log file in the input folder, alongside the files you validated, with information and errors about the validation process
Text in the console window, where you ran the script, with any errors in using the tool

note.para: The OVT is an open source tool written in Java. Application developers can download, view, and build the OVT source code from &GITHUBURL;.
